reviews.review_title: Suriya's Jai Bhim Deserves To Get An Oscar Award For The Best Movie, And Suriya Deserves To Get The Best Actor Award !!!
reviews.content: In a scene in Jai Bhim, a group of tribals man meet a police office who is heading an inquiry commission about the disappearance of three missing tribals who were being interrogated by the police about a theft case. One man tells him that he was once arrested by cops just for greeting them. Another tells him about how he was arrested just because he tried to slink away fearing them. A woman narrates how her husband was forced to 'confess' to a crime which he had not committed after the cops started molesting her. A young boy mentions that the police picked him up just because they could not get his father, and how that one incident made him a perennial suspect at school. These people are clearly damned if they did, and damned if they didn't.This scene is an echo of the scene that opens the film. We see many prisoners being let out of prison. A few cops from the surrounding police stations are waiting. As each prisoner comes out, he is asked for his caste. If they mention a dominant caste's name, they are asked to leave. But those who belong to a scheduled caste or scheduled tribe, they are told to stand in a corner, only for the waiting cops to pick them up as suspects in the many cases that remain unsolved in their station. When some of them complain that there are too few for them to foist cases on, they are told that they could accuses a few of committing more than one crime.With scenes like these, Jai Bhim powerfully captures the abuse and humiliation that is heaped upon the underprivileged by those in power and the kind of defiance it will take to get them justice. Like Visaaranai and the recent Kavalthurai Ungal Nanban, the film is also a fierce criticism of police brutality. The plot revolves around Rajakannu (Manikandan) and Sengani (Lijomol Jose), a couple who live at Konamalai near Viluppuram. They belong to the Irular tribe, and despite their poverty - they still cannot afford a brick house - they are contented and happy. Especially with their daughter Alli going to school and a second child on its way.But their happiness is dashed when cops come in search of Rajakannu over a robbery. The poor man has become the main suspect just because he happened to be the one who had visited the house where the robbery happened that day to catch a snake. Unable to find him, the police pick up the pregnant Sengani and a few other men from the tribe, including Rajakannu's brother Irutappan. Sengani is later let go - not before being beaten and kicked multiple times - but for Rajakannu and a couple of others, there is no respite from the harrowing violence unleashed upon by the men in khakhi. When Sengani hears that the three men have escaped and their whereabouts unknown, she reached out to Chandru (Suriya), a righteous lawyer who fights for the downtrodden. But can they uncover the truth with an entire system standing against them?Jai Bhim is an unexpected sophomore effort from TJ Gnanavel, who had previously directed the uneven drama Kootathil Oruvan. This is a film that is raw, real and brutal, with gritty filmmaking enhancing the solid writing. It effectively portrays the wrongs that are done to the underprivileged without seeming exploitative or overly melodramatic. Despite being one of the oldest communities in the country, these tribes do not even have any proof to show that they are its citizens and cannot even own a piece of the land. When Mythra (Rajisha Vijayan), a teacher who is part of an adult literacy programme, tries to get them a voter id, the local big shot, who belongs to a dominant caste, retorts, "Isn't it enough we have to request the lower castes to vote for us? Should we also go to the homes of these fellows?"Gnanavel gives us some terrific moments of defiance. Lijomol Jose is quietly powerful as Sengani, who gets a couple of rousing scenes when she turns down efforts at a compromise from cops. Manikandan, too, is effective and stands out in the scene when he urges his men to not give in as that will result in their community being branded as criminals. The director also portrays the intimacy between Sengani and Rajakannu in a charming manner.The film is based on a real-life incident involving Justice K Chandru, from his days as a lawyer. Suriya plays this role with the right amount of intensity and earnestness, which helps the character seem grounded even while the film and Sean Roldan's score try to build him up as a can-do-no-wrong superhero. In fact, his introduction scene wouldn't be out of place in a masala movie. But after Soorarai Pottru, this is another notable film for the star as a performer.And his scenes with Prakash Raj, who plays the inquiry commission head, Perumalsamy, give us calm and composed dialogue that act as a counterpoint to the flinching violence and the moving melodrama. The latter lends the role with a great deal of dignity to a character who believes one has to take up a little bit of authoritarianism to protect democracy. So, we have a lawyer who considers the police as the worst and a cop who finds lawyers the worst working together to ensure justice is done. Through these scenes, Gnanavel - as one of the judges in the film mentions - shows how justice can be upheld when law and order work hand in hand.There are only a couple of missteps. After a point, the violence begins to feel like torture porn, even though the film presents these episodes as flashbacks of events that happened over a day or two. And in a narrative sense, Chandru's efforts to unravel the mystery and his battle in court feels somewhat easier because there are no strong antagonists. Both Rao Ramesh as the advocate general and Guru Somasundaram as the public prosecutor never come across as formidable foes for Chandru in court. That said, as Chandru unravels one cover-up after another, the film makes us realise the extent to which unchecked power can go to maintain status quo.But these doesn't lessen the emotional impact of the film, which, along with films like Visaaranai, Kirumi and Kavalthurai Ungal Nanban, is a much-needed antidote to restore the balance in portrayals of the police in an industry overrun by the Singams and the Saamys.

The film is based on true story which was happened 28 years ago.Despite given an 'A' rating for its strong content, the film was real and brutal what we see it is similar to Visaranai and Kavalthurai Ungal Nanban. This is one of the best and powerful legal films. Thus, it's a must.watch.

reviews.review_title: "It will be quite an uphill battle."
reviews.content: There's some serious upvoting for this film here on IMDb; if not for a weighted averaging of the film's rating by viewers, this would be the number one movie of all time having just come out this year, and that by a wide margin. I thought the movie was good for it's portrayal of corrupt authorities taken down by a dedicated attorney, it hit on many of the points that social justice advocates clamor for here in this country. Based on a true story, one can only marvel at the dedication of a man like Chandru (Suriya), who utilized every bit of means and cunning to humiliate the brutal police authorities and their corrupt political allies. Many times it's a difficult story to watch, as the beatings and punishment doled out by district police against members of lower castes approach grotesquely inhumane treatment. Chandru's efforts eventually pay off, and it was inspiring to see him honored by the citizens he represented at the finale, reminiscent of that final scene of Gregory Peck in "To Kill A Mockingbird".One note of caution when coming to the IMDb title page - the names of characters listed in the credits don't match the corresponding identification of characters in the film. As an example, actress Lijo Mol Jose portrayed the agonized wife Sengoni in the credits, but in the film, captioning described her as 'Sannamma'. I'm not versed well enough in Indian nomenclature to know if that's a result of translation or some other factor. I would also question the narrative offered at the end of the story that stated the attorney portrayed in the picture was responsible for ninety six thousand cases in six years. To do that, he would have to have been involved with over forty cases per day, every single day for six years, with no days off!

reviews.review_title: Do Yourself A Favor, Leave Everything And Watch Suriya's Hard-Hitting Drama
reviews.content: Jai Bhim turned out to be a hard-hitting, raw and powerful court-room drama. The purpose of cinema is not just to entertain but also educate and empower the audience. The courtroom drama based movies are always engaging as the prosecutor and defendant both fight to solve the case with solid evidences and innumerable witnesses.Bollywood Films like "Damini", "Jolly LLB","Talvar" "Rustom", "Pink" or even "Section 375" have been immensely successful in keeping the audience engaged with impeccable dialogues and fantastic screenplay but what makes Jai Bhim different is the beautiful message on morality and equality of a tribal woman who fights for the justice of her husband.Jai Bhim is based on 1995 Habeas Corpus petition in which human right activist cum lawyer K. Chandru ( played by Suriya ), who takes up the case of Irular tribe couple (Rajakannu and Sengeni) where the husband is wrongly convicted by local police for stealing ornaments from village head's house.As Jai Bhim opens, we see that cops segregating the prisoners based on their caste. Among all the caste, the tribal people becomes the easy target for the cops to clear the pending cases under the influence of their political head. We also see how Rajakannu, the main accused in the jewelry case, is forcibly taken away from his family. The film goes back in the flashback mode where life of the tribal couple is beautiful in the serene village where they hone the skills of catching rat for their bosses. As their life progresses, in one of the event Rajakannu and his brothers are caught for the crime which they did not commit. They go through extreme level of police harassment and torture which will be very hard to digest and is completely raw. Enter Chandra a.k.a Suriya who takes up the case when Sengeni narrates the entire incident and request to help find her husband who as per police, has been absconding from the jail.Jai Bhim is one such hair-raising film which is definitely difficult to digest as it gives you goosebumps and eye-popping experience. Screenplay is the hero with nail-biting moments. Art direction is fine while Cinematography is excellent. Suriya is a knight in shining armor. Watch out for him in the second half when he questions the witnesses in the courtroom. It is unforgettable performance which should be lauded for its sheer brilliance. Among the actors - Manikandan and Lijomol Jose are mind-blowing with their natural performances. Prakash Raj does well as IG.Jai Bhim is an experience that needs to be lauded for its impeccable direction, electrifying performances and beautiful message. Excellent 4/5.

reviews.review_title: A hard-hitting courtroom drama on custodial violence!
reviews.content: Despite being over 2 hours and 45 minutes long, 'Jai Bhim' is an engaging, thoroughly entertaining watch backed by an astonishing real life story of custodial violence, police cover-ups and systemic corruption.Suriya plays a crusading lawyer, hell bent on revealing the truth behind three Irular (Scheduled Tribe) men who go missing while being in police custody.The superstar turns in an impeccable performance as he fastidiously chips away at the truth, only to discover layer upon layer of lies, caste hatred and cruelty.Despite having a big name star at his disposal, director T. J. Gnanavel deserves praise for letting the story take the driver's seat, never reducing to unnecessary 'massy' sequences or masala elements to drive the narrative forward.Lijimol Jose as the wife of Rajakannu (played by Manikandan) is an absolute force of nature in her role, delivering some of the best sequences in the film, turning in a performance a veteran would be proud of.Prakash Raj as usual excels in a supporting role while and Rajisha Vijayan had precious little screen time to make any sizeable impact.The music from Seal Roldan played very significant role, helping the audience to feel the pain of the beleaguered protagonists in the beginning and that of vindication and righteousness towards the climax.Jai Bhim does not rise up to the emotional highs of previous classic dramas based on custodial violence like Visaranai (2015) or Naandhi (2021) but is an immensely engrossing watch. Recommended!

Turns out, the movie is based on a real-life incident from 1993.In times when being a policeman is mostly glorified in Indian cinema, I wasn't expecting a movie about police brutality, something that's usually swept under the rugs, which makes this an important film in Tamil film industry and thanks to streaming services, in Indian Cinema.The storytelling does a great job of making you care enough for Rajakannu and Sengani (both brilliantly played, with Lijomol being the show stealer in this movie) that you empathize with them throughout the movie. Parts of the movie were brutal and hard to watch, don't be surprised if you find yourself shouting "Okay that's enough! STOP!" at the events that unfold. Suriya and Prakash Raj play their respective roles with just enough intensity, nothing over the top with this one. Acting by all of the support cast was very well done.As much as this film is about police brutality, this is also about casteism, which is still prevalent in our great country. Movies, both good and bad ones, in the past on this topic have been made, but you can tell if the script is trying too hard to highlight the caste system. This one, I thought, did it just right and didn't overdo it.If you HAVE to, you can find things wrong with the movie - some cinematic liberty, the "comedic" elements, some "mass moments", were all necessary IMO. That said, this isn't the kind of movie you find flaws in, but the kind that you watch, and learn and grown from as a person. So, I'd request that you simply appreciate the filmmaking, empathize with the characters and learn a thing or two takeaways for real life.

reviews.review_title: A riveting and raw legal drama with mind-blowing performances from Suriya and Lijumol
reviews.content: Director Gnanavel captures the raw nature of police brutality with a high degree of realism, and every scene was emotionally charged. Suriya brings another firebrand performance after SP, and delivers with his impeccable dialogue delivery and mannerism. I'm glad they didn't add any unnecessary mass/commercial scenes just because it is a Suriya film, and even the songs went along with the story instead destroying the pace. Another important mention is Lijomol Jose's performance as the Irular women who nailed it in every scene.If I had to nitpick some minor negatives in the movie. It would be the antagonists. While they did a satisfactory job, perhaps having a more intelligent lawyer to counter Suriya would have added to more intensity, however this barely impacts the film. The runtime could have also been shortened by 10-15 minutes.Jai Bhim is a fantastic movie and frankly I was more emotionally moved by it than Soorarai Pottru. The movie is an eye-opener to police brutality, but isn't over the top in its police bashing either. Instead it provides nuanced perspectives from well-meaning police officers (pay attention to Prakash Raj's role) in an attempt to support a more just legal system.Rating: 9.5/10.

reviews.review_title: JAI BHIM is Real, Brutal and Thoughtful
reviews.content: Jai Bhim is real. No doubt about it. A real story portrayed with gripping narration. Makes you fixed on the movie. Jai Bhim is brutal. Yes, the horror of stereotyping people. It breaks your heart throughout the event. Jai Bhim is thoughtful in the sense that it will keep you thinking about who is really the culprit in today's society. Finally it will gives you a silver lining throughout the dark episode. An intellectual war between constitution and unconstitutional surpassing caste creed and divisons.Now coming to the movie, Suriya plays the role of a dedicated lawyer. He works for upliftment of the downtrodden and provides justice. He plays the part well, no nonsense behavior normally done by the protagony of south movies. The antagony is well represented. Means he is perfect outwardly but a devil inside. A genuine depiction of villains in real world. The movie progresses as a war between justice and injustice that finally gives an optimistic ending. Like a ray appearing in the dark. The message of awareness that we should cultivate rearding oppression done by law keepers is a mandatory nowadays. I shall remember movies like Jai bhim and Ardh Satya regarding the social issues. Both are good though opposed to one another in story.Prakash Raj is good to watch esp in Positive role. The performances are praiseworthy. All possible edges are covered makes you seated. The BGM is of heightened feel. It is a positive themed movie. One of the best from south. Recommended for social issues in Indian context. It's a strong point also that the movie is based upon a true story, but there is a minor political issue attached with it. It is modified so is slightly unreal with unreal vibes throughout. So a 90/100.

reviews.review_title: Captivating, well acted n thought provoking. Not a single dull moment. Definitely deserves an Oscar.
reviews.content: If Atticus Finch is the greatest movie hero, then Chandru is the most underrated real life hero.This movie is a sobering reminder of the injustice and lack of accountability that plagues my beloved India.The poor dwellings in the mountainous forests reflected the state of deep racial problems and social injustice that still exists in my beloved India.The guy (Suriya) who played Chandru gave an amazing performance.This is my first film of Surya n I have become a huge fan of him.Also this is my first film of the lead actress Lijo Mol Jose and she gave an intense performance and her character Sengkani will make even the toughest skin to feel sad.This movie has the most brutal scenes of police brutality. More horrific than most horror films and very very frightening when u know that the movie is based on true events.The real life judgment of Rajakannu vs State of Tamil Nadu & Ors, has Parvathi's statement on the torture that she and her husband had suffered, the reality seems far worse than art.

JAI BHIM (Hindi Movie, Amazon Prime,2021) - Bravo!!! If you have to see only one movie in 2021, watch this one. It's unsettling, shocking, real. In the era of SQUID GAME and Suryavanshi fantasies, we need such real life stories. I feel so much guilty that we are still carrying the burden of this 2500 years old rotten caste system where our fellow human beings are still treated worse than animals. As if the actors have not acted, it feels like I am watching CCTV footage! There is minimal heroism, maximum expression. There is not much court room drama, still the pace of the story is intense. The police and system which were supposed to protect us, provide everybody equal rights for survival, in reality literally killing people based on their surnames!!! :-( This movie based on a real life story on tribal rights made me sad, this movie made me hopeful too! Hats Off to all the Actor-Director-Story Writers and entire crew members. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Suriya & Co. deliver a hard-hitting social issue drama! [+73%]
reviews.content: It's always nice to see a star like Suriya move away from a typical masala flick for Diwali and come up with a hard-hitting courtroom drama based on actual events. In the film, he is more of a tool that helps enact justice for the oppressed victims. There's no showy entry, songs that praise him to the skies, or stock heroines who exist only to admire him. Instead, the film focuses more on the tribal characters played by Manikandan and Lijomol (both excellent) and the series of unfortunate events that they go through.Police brutality has been a sensitive topic, touched upon by very few films and filmmakers, even when we keep hearing several such cases in the news. Films like Visaranai and Karnan paved the way for TJ Gnanavel's Jai Bhim to tell a harrowing social issue without the need to be preachy. Jai Bhim's first hour is a somewhat disturbing watch, with the cries of the oppressed both tugging at your heartstrings and coming across as slightly amplified. There's no subtlety at play. The punches are wholly felt, the screams are heard loud and clear. If you still don't, Sean Roldan's woeful score will drive the point home.But the film gets infinitely better in its final hour. While the finale isn't exactly unpredictable, the journey of getting there is riveting. Both Suriya and Prakash Raj deliver the goods gracefully - not for once, getting in our faces with loud monologues. At a length of 2h 45m, Jai Bhim works due to its performances and topical relevance. Glad that a mainstream audience gets to see it on OTT.

"Jai Bhim" is a Crime - Drama movie in which we watch a man being accused and arrested as a thief. His wife with the help of a lawyer try very hard to bring justice and find out what exactly happened.I have to admit that I did not have high expectations from this movie but soon enough I understood that it will be an amazing movie. The plot is very interesting and it contained plenty of unexpected plot twists that made it even more interesting. The interpretations of Suriya who played as Chandru and Lijo Mol Jose who played as Senggeni were very good and they made the difference. In addition to this, the direction which was made by T. J. Gnanavel who is also the writer, it was equally good and he presented very well both the plot and his main characters, something that made possible for the audience to relate to them. Lastly, I have to say that "Jai Bhim" is an interesting drama movie and I highly recommend everyone to watch it.

We Indians live in binaries since our votes are mostly emotionally driven. When we love a film star in the film or the cause it discusses, we are hypercharged and want to give it a 10. Just the way Vishwaroopoam was. Vishwaroopam had 9.8/10 with more than 30k votes back in 2013 when Indian films barely touched 10k votes (pre-jio era).The same is happening with Jai Bhim, which is currently at 9.6/10 in above 70k votes. Diving a little deeper into the vote analysis, it shows 62k votes is 10/10. That would mean, the film has been voted as one of the rarest of rare flawless pieces of art to ever come out in the world of films. I think I have rated about 4 films 10/10. Not to say this does not deserve a 10/10. But the film receiving a perfect score from more than 88% of the total votes is an extreme coincidence, especially when the top 1000 voters on IMDb have a weighted average of 4/10 - not 6, not 8, only 4/10 for the film. The funny thing is, 3.5% of them have voted it 1/10 as well. Let's compare this with another fan-driven top 10 IMDb film "The Dark Knight". The Dark Knight has a combined percentage of 10/10 and 1/10 of 46.3% against Jai Bhim's cumulative 91.5% in 10/10 and 1/10.Not saying this could not be possible, but this clearly seems like a large section of the audience is voting on the basis of the biased emotional rush. We saw similar instances with Wanted (2008) when this had just come out. However, this has reduced by a huge margin for Salman Khan films in the last 5-6 years with growing awareness on the mediocrity of bhai's films where even the fans now feel illiterate on praising his work. But considering the Hero worship in the Tamil and the Telugu films industry combined with a cause many people strongly resonate with, I am sure many things have been overlooked while judging this particular film. We saw this happen with Baahubali as well, no doubt it is an entertaining film but not without flaws. I am sure, so is this and many other such films.

reviews.review_title: Casteism does exist in 21st century India...
reviews.content:
There are 36 tribes in TamilNadu. Most from these tribes depend on agriculture, forests and cultivation for their livelihood. This is a story of 4 who belong to one such tribe who work for upper caste in rat infestation control and catching snakes in their homes. The oppressor and the oppressed... a habeas corpus case... court drama ... movie does succeed in portraying a heinous gruesome picture of the atrocities and systematic violence that are being committed by the police, the upper caste, the justice system and the government against these tribes. A bitter reality... in last 5 years In the last five years, a total of 300 caste-related murders have been reported in Tamil Nadu and most victims were Dalits. At least two Dalits are assaulted every hour in 21st-century India, and every day, three Dalit women are raped, two Dalits are murdered and two Dalit homes are torched on average. Over 200 million Dalits, who comprise nearly 17% of India's population, face the threat of such violence daily (Ref: Wire)
The apotheosis of the protagonist and few unnecessary jail sequences however takes away the focus from the underlying tribal issue .. but it does not fail to deliver a strong message and demands one to introspect.. thought provoking, based on true story .. Surya brings the perception in story telling to an 'unfortunately a truism' .. a great watch ..
I never ever seen movie this type.. extraordinary acting... intresting & emotional story.... fabulous execution ..best movie of suraya ever... masterpiece must watch....

I don't even want to talk about acting performances because I don't think I'm quite qualified to talk about it. Suriya sir did it again after Soorarai Pottru and supporting cast deserves a special mention, TBH, they performed better than most bollywood actors. Indian cinema deserves more movies like this. Thank you Prime Video for producing such high quality movies.

The injustice and dictatorship showcased somehow prevails in every part of the world, not just India or its one state and its tribe. Yaa, whether it drills down to the level of torture shown in this movie maybe a point to debate, and I am not the correct person to judge all that.Coming to incidents shown, power pack performance by leads or the spine chilling atmosphere is all on top and needs no explanation. I mean, I had seen Suriya's many films and this one is not behind any.But, this being said, I still see few hiccups and those, as per me, should have been taken care of. Somehow, I tend to compare this courtcase with Jolly LLB. Even if both are totally opposite yet they ooze out same problem: injustice to lower class or below poverty line people. And that's when I see Boman Irani giving tight fight to Arshad Warsi. However, in here, the story seemed focused on solving the case and some how, inclined towards Suriya, as a lawyer. PP wasn't doing much, and Attorney General's entry looked gloomy, naive and just for the sake. I mean, if this story is based on real life incidents, then was that person unprepared to anything. And also, if that is the case, and he was a probable MP candidate, then who made him to whatever level he was. At this stage, people do their level best to win rather just mock around and at the end face the blow.Anyways, if to keep aside that aspect, the movie is good and no doubt worth a watch.

Technical team work was good , especially makeup artists and art work . Cinematography was good . Sean Roldan music was mind blowing . Only negative I felt bit lag in few places . Atlast a emotional , intense and hard-hitting movie , a very important movie that should be watched . A must watch and highly recommend .

One of the exceptional, outstanding movies of Hot Chocolate, Hot Shot, Actor Suriya (Younger Killer Looks). Court drama that is so thoroughly astonishing & engaging right from the start of the movie. Distinctively unique, even from the very first 5-10 minutes. Definitely from the lines of "Visaranai", I am getting used to the recent cinematic legal works such as Nerkonda Paarvai, Ponmagal Vandhal etc, these kind of thought-provoking scripts is fast catching up as a trending inspiration for all film makers.In his Brave & Bold attempt, Director TJ Gnanavel 's Jai Bhim (2 hours, 45 minutes long) flawlessly speaks about custodial violence, police cover-up, systemic corruption at a huge level, that is so hard to logically digest or reason out the whole truth and finally there would be no end to the entire picture. The blame game is never ending.I can add to this saying that Jai Bhim is actually truly-brutally honest, clear-cut reality filled with heart-wrenching scenes, that is sure to leave you feeling that there is more bad in this world than good.One can praise Actor Suriya for his super star performance that is so shockingly awesome, only to discover embarrassing sheets of lies, caste hatred and cruelty. Actor suriya has done a wonderful job of acting so well & so concealed, that I just forgot him in the process, being so much involved in the amazing narration of this deeply appealing, story-telling method that the writer TJ Gnanavel has crafted & adopted.Huge round of applause for the extreme level beautiful Cinematography of S. R. Kathir, which gave this movie it s core life & the element of suspense. Music by Sean Roldan is noteworthy in it s own way, made me feel pain and all kinds of emotions throughout the film. Other actors namely Prakash Raj who shines seperately as usual due to his sensible acting portions for a supporting role, while Rajisha Vijayan, Lijomol Jose, Rao Ramesh deserve a standing ovation and especially K. Manikandan who earned the merit of a special mention. One wonders how he actually did all those gruesome scenes.The director unquestionably has to be awarded for the stupendous success of this movie which solely entertains family audiences without depending upon masala factor or "mass"components.I would definitely watch it again as it was based on detailed portrayal of true events & people!Hats off to the entire Cast & Crew, Team of Jai Bhim! Cheers!Original Content By Ar Deepika Dhilip.

reviews.review_title: Taut screenplay, stark realism and high class acting
reviews.content: This movie is a disturbing and traumatic watch dealing as it does with extended scenes of police brutality in the jail premises. The plot is about a tribal who is wrongfully arrested for stealing jewellery and police use third degree to force him to confess. The narrative is gripping as it first shows the police version and alternates with scenes of actually what happened.Director TJ Gnanvel deserves credit for making a riveting movie based on a taut screenplay focusing on the oppression faced by the marginalised tribals. There is raw realism as we see them catching rats for food and struggling to make an existence with dignity. Their way of life both in the sad and happy moments are shown well. I felt that that the director has been inspired by the work of Shyam Benegal and Prakash Jha.Limo Mol Jose who has played the role of the suffering wife has done a superb job. No less impressive is actor K Manikandan as the harassed victim. Suriya plays a brave lawyer- crusader who takes on the entire police department in order to deliver justice to the pregnant wife of the tribal. Veteran Prakash Raj is impressive as IG, police. The acting of all is high class.The courtroom scenes have been shot skillfully and are absorbing. It is clear that the self respect , dignity and human rights of the tribal community are on trial here against the all powerful police and bureaucratic state machinery. The movie has excellent cinematography and editing.Despite the scenes of excessive police brutality (custodial third degree), the movie should be on the "must see list" due to its overall excellence.

reviews.review_title: Not just a movie but a harsh truth...
reviews.content: What a masterpiece well deserved 10 rating movie. This movie is based on true incident. A well known case that's still been discussed by people's of South and now the whole country is talking about this movie.

*) K Reviews *) ( ( We already know this kind of treatment happens everywhere, everyday even now but what can we do? A horrific and truthful fact is that even now there are daily five deaths under police custody in India recorded, and this is coming from official govenment data records. This movie is fantastically eye opening, litteraly full of chills. I wish that those who are really accused for this horrible crime may treated with chilli powder in their eyes day and night.

reviews.review_title: Jai Bhim- Heart in the right place but...
reviews.content: Looks like those who have watched Jai Bheem are already divided in two groups. The ones belonging to the segment which has superliked this innocuously immature movie and are championing it to be a messiah of their lost ideology and those who are considering this as a threat to their existence. It has a rating of 9.6 on IMDB and yet to come in the top 250 list of the database provided by the site even after securing nearly 56k votes when this review is being written, a proof of the fact that something is wrong with the metrics and the effervescent rating will overcome the emotional doldrums and will stabilize soon after the initial emotions doze off. This shows how people belonging to any particular political ideology have strongly voted in favor of this movie. On the other hand, the way this movie is being slammed by some so called 'Film Pundits' or the 'Protectors of the nation' on several social media platforms show their unnecessary fear of losing their propaganda politics for a mere movie. The real metrics of IMDB will come into action when the initial zeal will die off from both the parties. Wait till that day to be too biased by any judgmental review.'Jai Bhim' is an honest endeavour to champion the spirit of protecting the rights of our indigenous people. The movie has its heart in the right place. The depiction of the brutality meted out to our innocent tribals invokes pity. But that in no way makes a movie scale the heights of greatness. In no way, Jai Bhim succeeds in being obstinate to the popular demands and reach new heights of glory in terms of movie making. It is melodramatic from the beginning to the end and even though it has its effervescent moments of greatness it fails to live with it.The movie is a strange admixture of movie making of the present-day style of real-life storytelling and the bland, over emotional way of direction, reminiscent of the 90s style of creating a movie. The entry of the protagonist in many scenes are made to invite whistle from the audience, uncalled for a movie belonging to this genre at this age when people expect a movie with this much sincerity in its intention to be grounded, uncompromising and undeterred by the lure of commercial gains.But the pursuits of 'Jai Bhim' are unfathomably ambitious, to an extent that it fails to be realistic in its portrayal of the plight of the tribal people. Right from the inception of the story, where a sarpanch is pressurizing the SP to catch an innocent tribal till the trial in the court in presence of a buffoonery AG of the state, the movie is bubbled to shed its earthliness and thus fails to arouse any real emotion. The torture scenes are brutal, naked yet they do not conform to the storyline and appear to be exaggerated.Surya as the protagonist is good but at times appears to be lost in agendas and a weak screenplay does not allow him to come out of the shell. Prakash Raj is hyperideologist and does not have any connection with the ground realities. The ones donning the roles of Raja and Singani are brilliant though.The reason why communist flags are being shown again and again and those went missing while the narration was leading to a conclusive end is nebulous. Communists or their ideologies or flags have been shown as mere agenda or objects appearing only when the screenplay needed them not when the situation demanded them. The intentions of the petty police officials are unclear and why the AG is hellbent on supporting them even when he is refuting the SP is also equally hazy. The theory of monetary benefits could not be well established.Overall, this movie should be hailed for its honest intention in portraying the plight of the oppressed sections of the society. Only the execution could have been better.The cherubic style of the little kid is the best takeaway from this movie.My Rating- 7 out of 10.

Review By Kamal KJai Bhim is said to be a story inspired by the real experiences of Justice Chandru. The movie holds the mirror to the ugly side of caste discrimination in the country even today. The fact that many people languish in jails without an opportunity to prove their innocence and the way the system treats them is highly disturbing.The first half of the film starts with the description of the lifestyle of the tribals. Director Gnanavel has shown their innocence, how they are deprived of a decent living and recognition, and how they are discriminated against in society. Once the crime scene starts, the police brutality is very disturbing and is certainly not for the faint-hearted.Suriya enters the proceedings almost half an hour into the film but you do not miss him. Sinna Thalli narrates the story to him and that episode ends with a heart-warming scene. Chandru is disturbed by the fact how Sinna Thalli can not even sign the petition but it is immediately followed by a shot in which Sinna Thalli's daughter writes her name on a slate. The scene indicates the fate of tribals and also carries a message that only education can change their fate.The courtroom drama follows after that. If there is one drawback for the film, these are the portions. We expect courtroom drama to be intense from both sides. But then, the other side is so meek. It is although all the evidence walks up to Chandru and submits themselves. And, there are the culprit police who admit to everything with minimal grilling.But then, we do not feel that or finish the movie with that feeling. The director constantly makes us feel the pain of the affected family and pulls the heartstrings with emotions. Lijo Mol Jose who played Sinna Thalli plays a crucial role here. She has put up a spectacular show so that audience will connect to her plight. Even though the climax is not spectacular, we connect to the cause and cherish the justice done to Rajanna's family.Despite being based on a true incident, showing some things in the film by changing it is also one of the negative points of the film.Performances -I didn't felt that Surya acted in this movie, I felt that he is the original Chandru in each and every bit and scene of the movie.The next two standout characters are not the seniors like Rao Ramesh and Prakash Raj. It is Manikandan and Lijo Mol Jose who played Rajanna and Sinna Thalli who were exceptional. Rao Ramesh and Prakash Raj were good in the roles they are given. We somehow feel Rao Ramesh's characterization needs some more fireworks. Rajisha Vijayan is okay in a small role. The rest of the characters are fine to the extent they are expected to perform.All in all, Jai Bhim is a Good watch on Amazon Prime Video.

reviews.review_title: Jai Bhim's subject is too extraordinary to be handled by such ordinary execution but Suriya's power-packed performance makes it a worth watch.
reviews.content:
Jai Bhim (2021) :
Movie Review -Tamil Cinema has brought some really good films this year. Not just good but meaningful ones. Films like 'Pebbles', 'Mandela' and 'Karnan' have brought major social issues into spotlight. Director T. J. Gnanavel's latest offering 'Jai Bhim' is another superb addition in the list. However, it's like a stone turned into Silver when it could have been Gold, if wanted. Jai Bhim attempts a very sensitive issue in a hard hitting narrative but while doing so, it misses a few things that could have made it a Sensational Film. Anyways, it's a great one time watch and surely does some much needed hammering on "The System".Based on a true incident in 1993, the film follows Sengani (Lijomol Jose) and Rajakannu (K. Manikandan), a couple from the Irular tribe. The latter is convicted by the police due, and later goes missing from the police station. Senggeni seeks the help of an advocate Chandru (Suriya) to seek justice for her husband. It's not a fight between low caste and high caste or corrupt police officers, but it's a fight against the entire system. When the first born of the lands are treated like slaves, your blood surely boils but what can these low grade people do against highly influential people? Law is same for all and that's the biggest weapon they have. Jai Bhim is too disturbing and devastating at moments. Some scenes in the film are unbearable (for weak hearted) but because its storyline demands the same uncompromised vision, you don't get a chance to point a finger at it.The performance of Suriya is the biggest reason why this film can be recommended to everyone. Supporting him, Prakash Raj, K. Manikandan, Lijomol Jose, Rao Ramesh, Rajisha Vijayan and M. S. Bhaskar put out their best in their individual roles. The entire acting unit in Jai Bhim is commendable. Talking about the flaws, the film fails to remain steady throughout the narrative. This entire thing takes 164 minutes to wrap up the same old Ambedkar-oriented stuff, why? That grip over the content is not tight enough to hold such a socially important topic.When it comes to the positives, one has to mention the writer first. Gnanavel's on-paper draft is astonishing and eye-opening stuff. Sadly, his direction is not upto the mark as required but it's fairly decent. In some scenes, you just can't stop loving his directorial skills. For instance, whenever there's Suriya on the screen thinking of something, you hear that intense background music which creates that atmosphere around you. Those speeches on morals, fundamental rights and equality will end up with your claps. Unfortunately, some scenes have been dragged for no reason and over-dramatized for the sake emotional quotient. Also, the predictable nature of the script is too typical. It works sometimes because you cannot bear seeing those brutal and painful scenes of obscene tyranny. Excluding couple of mistakes done by the director, nothing seems to bother too much. Jai Bhim has an extraordinary story to tell, which deserves your viewing but it gets an ordinary vision to showcase it on screen. Had it been taken care of, Jai Bhim would have been a nationwide sensation.RATING - 6.5/10*

reviews.review_title: Outstanding movie with very good message
reviews.content: After hearing all the rave reviews, got to watch the movie at last. Initial 30 minutes was little slow and that's the only reason for 9 stars, but once picked up momentum, could not even take eyes off the screen for its excellent storytelling and cinematography.Although everybody contributed to the success and message to reach the audience, three people stood out from the rest, they are Surya, Manikandan and Lijimol Jose. Although Surya hardly smiles in this movie, people will him for his excellent acting and emotions, very good movie from him once again after 'Soorarai Pottru'.Keeping the communal aspects apart, it has really good message for everyone, how important education is for everyone to grow and speak up. Moreover how courts in India are still doing their best for justice.Expecting a lot more movies from Surya like this! 👍

In a country where justice is a luxury, and can easily be bought if you're in the right position or quite well off. How would a pregnant woman from a very lower-cast, with no money would fight a case against the system and the corruption deep rooted within those who are the face of this so called system... win her battle to find what really happened to her husband and love? An angel in the form of a true lawyer will be by her side, but it's not going to be an easy one--so tighten your belts and get on this roller-coaster of emotions with a box of tissue-paper by your side. I'm actually numb with my eyes welled up with tears as I type this.Beautiful ending though. This is what I call a true content-oriented movie which no Khan, or so called Bhai can win against.I don't know who directed and produced it, but it's a gem that everyone needs to watch and collect(as in add it to your movie-collection). Hats off to you and your team! **wipes the tears** *sniff* *sniff* :(

reviews.review_title: A gut wrenching and heartbreaking film that is a must watch for everyone.
reviews.content: This is not an entertainment film. Jai Bhim is more of an educational film that needs to be seen by everyone. Jai Bhim shows us a reality that we conveniently ignore and overlook, because it's too ugly and depressing, and we just want beauty and positivity in our life. We are fed with movies like Sooryavanshi, where policemen have superhuman abilities and are always acting in the best interests of the people, but the true picture is very different from the one shown to us by the likes of Rohit Shetty. We as human beings do not believe in the concept of "always punch up", we derive pleasure out of exploiting the poor, weak and the downtrodden. We have turned ourselves into the monsters that we used to read about in the fairytales as kids. 'Jai Bhim' shows us the mirror that we just don't have the courage to look into.WHAT'S GOOD IN THE FILM :1. Suriya leads from the front with his confident portrayal of Chandru. Every dialogue that he delivers is said with full conviction, and creates a deep impact on the viewer making us believe that a person like him would surely embed fear into the minds of his opponents. Suriya is just outstanding in the film.2. While some movies find pleasure in showing policemen as superheroes who can do no wrong, Jai Bhim doesn't shy away from showing the reality. Extreme level of police torture, kicking and beating women, implicating innocent people in false cases and arresting them, taking orders from politicians and rich people, it's all there in the film. The movie throws light on the mindset of corrupt police officers who don't have any kind of respect for any kind of law.3. The movie throws light on the life of people who belong to an extremely lower caste, people who aren't even considered worthy of having a voter I card or a proper house made of bricks. These lower caste people are left to do the dirty work for us, but in return they aren't even considered as equals. They don't get any kind of empathy, compassion or love from the upper caste people, all they get is hatred and disdain. After watching a movie like this, some introspection is necessary, we need to think about what we have made ourselves, what are we teaching our children. What kind of human beings are we, if we can't even treat others with the same love and respect that we want for ourselves ?4. The climax of the film is bound to give you goosebumps and make you cry. Your heart needs a special kind of medical attention if you don't get emotional at the sight of a mother and her daughter folding hands thanking Chandru, while getting drenched in the rain. The final scene is bound to make you cry a little, but at the same time will bring a smile to your face.WHAT'S NOT SO GOOD IN THE FILM :1. The lawyers are too weak. In every court battle, Chandru (Suriya) wins quite easily. I agree, he is well versed with all the rules of the court, has all the facts, but his opponents are shown to be extremely incompetent, with nothing in their mind to counter Chandru's statements. I don't think it's that easy to win a court battle. In fact, the prosecution often ends up taking advantage of the loopholes in the Legal system of India.2. The movie is too long. The pacing is also an issue here. Every scene that has Suriya in it is extremely powerful, but once he moves out of the scene, the movie slows down. This movie would not have been the same without Suriya's stellar act. Jai Bhim's inconsistent screenplay and direction do not allow for it to be called a great film.Overall, Jai Bhim is a movie that deserves to be seen by each one of us. It may not be a perfect film, but one needs to ignore the shortcomings in a movie like this. Despite all the things that weigh it down, 'Jai Bhim' remains an extremely strong and relevant film with powerful performances from Suriya, Lijo Jose and Prakash Raj. Jai Bhim is the story of defiance, standing up for what's right and fighting against the evil society that doesn't even consider you worthy of being called a human being. 'Jai Bhim' is a must watch.

reviews.review_title: Suriya isn't competing with anyone. He is on the league of taking Tamizh Cinema to next level!
reviews.content: Another proud moment for Anbaana fans and Tamizh Cinema Rasiga koottam.Jai Bhim isn't a film that will be forgotten in a hurry. The film talks about the injustice that happened to the Irular community. It is not a caste film, it's all about equality. Very bold direct portrayal of casteist discrimination & demonic police brutality. Another landmark film from Jyotika-Suriya's 2D Entertainment.No forced romance, no song-dance, no stunts, no needless heroism! Nadippin Nayagan is 100% the Kadhaiyin Nayagan here. Immense maturity shown by the star actor to let the story take prominence and play within it's boundaries! Yes, Suriya steals the show but special mention to Lijo Mol Jose and Manikandan, they have given their heart & soul to the film, stellar performances from both of them and the whole cast. Full credit to Tha. Se Gnanavel for discovering & bringing out such a case - it's brutal, twisted and the intensity in the film is supreme. A must-watch powerful courtroom drama.

The strength of this film lies in its evocative performances and direct portrayal of its subject matter. When covering the issue of caste discrimination, it does not shy away from all the horrific ways the authorities inflict injustice on the tribal group. Throughout the film, they exist to the police only as useful scapegoats to inflate their arrest records as they don't have the wealth or social status to defend themselves. This is all portrayed in a tense and brutal way as the actors always show they are in constant anguish and it never shies away from direct violence (which got too much at times). It strikes a fine balance between cynicism and hope, as embodied by the main lawyer character who is a reluctant hero and is pessimistic about the missing men but is defiant enough to try to find them anyway. My main concern with the film was the odd editing as time skips around a lot in very confusing ways, especially when there are so many characters.

reviews.review_title: Jai Bhim, Jai Chandru, Jai Hind!
reviews.content: Jai Bhim, a film based on a true story, inspired by real events. This is a movie that will move even the coldest of hearts.Jai Bhim focuses on police brutality against tribals/lower caste people. The way the cops will falsely arrest them and charge them with whatever crimes they feel like, along with how they have no way to fight back against this oppression. The storyline is absolutely fantastic, it has twists and turns that will have you questioning what really happened. It gets the viewer emotionally invested in the plights of it's main characters Rajakannu and his wife Sengeni, two tribals living a simple, yet happy life until Rajakannu is falsely imprisoned for committing a crime, he didn't commit, and is beaten to death by the local cops while in jail.These tribals or low caste people, don't even own the land they live on or have documents to show they exist as people. The movie follows the lawyer Chandru, who is one of the few people who seems to care about justice for everyone, not just the rich or higher caste people. He doesn't charge a single cent for human rights cases and when Sengeni comes to him asking for help, they fight an uphill battle to prove what really happened to Rajakannu. It may seem like just a single case, but in reality it's a turning point, it's a chance at a better life for all tribals.What makes this movie so great is the absolutely fantastic acting performances delivered by Lijomol Jose (Sengeni), K. Manikandan (Rajakannu), Suriya (Chandru), Rajisha Vijayan (Mythra), Prakash Raj (IG Perumalsamy) and the rest of the supporting cast. Every single one of them puts their absolute heart and soul into the characters they're playing. They bring them to life on screen and now that we are viewing them as real, live, living people, we can't help but become emotionally invested in the movie and the story and plight of the Irula people. When Sengeni cries, your heart wrenches at the sound, when her daughter Alli Rajakannu (Baby Joshika Maya) screams for her daddy or mummy it will being tears to your eyes.A brilliant, raw and powerful storyline, combined with a talented cast to bring it to life and you've got an amazing movie. The fact it's based on real events that have happened, just reaches out to the minds, hearts and souls of every single person who sees it. The director knew what he was doing, what he wanted from his cast and production team, and in the end everyone delivered.There is no big dance numbers in the movie, though there is a song or two. They are well placed to not disrupt the movies story, but that still help to build on it. The songs themselves are really lovely and I'll definitely be listening to them a few more times.A beautiful movie from Tamil cinema, which deals with real life issues that conveys a powerful message to its audience. This is truly what cinema is about, not the trash that is thrown out, a dime a dozen nowadays in Hollywood. A extremely well deserved 10/10 from me.Jai Bhim, Jai Chandru, Jai Hind! Justice for all!

Watched two excellent movies back to back- Chhorii and Jai Bhim.Both tough to watch. Please watch it. Do watch it.This was harder to watch than the scariest horror movies. Breaks my heart to know this happened to real people. My soul hurts to think of what people suffer in the name of caste, social status, presumptions based on appearance, their financial status.This may be a story from Tamil Nadu but it is one that happens across the country to those from the so called lower social strata.With actors like Suriya at the helm, the film was bound to get attention and traction but it is the team of actors, script writers, director et al who pulled this together.Lijomol Jose had a focal role and she stood her ground with a stellar performance.The brilliance of an actor like Prakash Raj shines through in movies like this. His nuanced performance, umpteen moments where he conveys everything with the mere movement of eyes, a raised eyebrow and so forth is fascinating to watch.Of course, the hard work that went into both the making and the performance by Suriya is evident and applause worthy.What stands above all are the real people whose story this is. If only these stories brought to light on celluloid would trigger a real change in mindsets of the people and the society at large, it would be a big win.

reviews.review_title: Feel emotional and inspired. Take a bow.
reviews.content: Just finished watching this master piece. There is a lot I want to say here, but I want to start by saying, "Thank you".Really appreciate the screenplay and the story telling. The character development is spot on. Nothing was abrupt, nothing was vague, nothing got elevated. The movie establishes the under lying problem more than the actors, which is so refreshing to see. reviews.review_title: This movie is an hour too long
reviews.content: I just don't understand why this movie gets the love it does. This just feels like a diluted "Visaranai", with nothing new to say to the audience. The story progresses in snail's pace and it's oh so predictable and cliche. Yes, I get it, it's based on a true story, but what matters in cinema is not what the story is, but how it is presented.Jai Bhim isn't by any account a bad movie. I think it's a decent one. But like literally every legal drama movie ever made in Tamil cinema, it falls victim to overestimating its appeal. Do we really need the exaggerated slow-mo's, the over dramatic profiles and the intrusively annoying musical numbers to have effectively told this story?The worst part about this movie is its characters. They lack an enormous amount of depth. I still wonder why the character of M S Baskhar even existed in the movie, if not to annoy us with literally every word he says, effectively bogging the movie down with him. Don't get me wrong, I love the guy and think he's an amazing actor, but he was so poorly written overall in this movie. And that is true for Suriya as well. The character has nothing to set him apart from what you might expect from an exaggerated "goody" lawyer.The movie is 160-something minutes long. That is a painstakingly long time to have to sit through a movie with so little substance. If they had cut down on everything they thought would make it a commercial movie, and had stuck with only the meat of it, they could have made it into an amazing 90-100 minute experience of high spirits and emotions. But no, you just had to drag it for as long as you did.I don't hate the movie, if not for feeling like it wasted one extra hour of my attention it deserved to have. It's at least a decent one, but nothing close to the amount of praise it gets. But hey, I'm in the minority here, so who knows...

reviews.review_title: Decent Cinematic venture which is a good entertainer despite the shortcomings
reviews.content: This review will focus on why I am demoting it from 10 stars to 8. Majority of people have it 10 and this review will be explaining my ratingI went into the film with a pre-existing judgement that it will be a very preachy unoriginal story relying on identity politics and though I can't say I was completely proved wrong,I have to admit that I did enjoy the film well.'Jai Bhim' has a very boring unoriginal first act and a short second act and has a very black-or-white approach with only three class of humans:The Oppressors,The Opressed and The Savior. The real world never works that way and there needs to be a lot more nuance in depicting an issue of such magnitude. When I said three classes,I meant that those belonging to any label has no other personality trait other than being Extremely Evil,Extremely helpless or Extremely Virtuous. This type of apporach would work well for a film like 'Karnan' which has a very dreamy,mythical and fairy-tale approach,a reason why the film is so great. But for a film like 'Jai Bhim' which is supposed to be grounded in reality and only having slight dramatization,this falls flat and feels very "rubbing it on the face".But after the first 1/3 rd,the film becomes a very entertaining court-room thriller despite its dramatisations and takes a more nuanced approach to the issue and its depiction even though 'The Saviour' character of Surya still remains an unrealistically holy and virtuous persona.The final act where justice is served was satisfying and brought this entertainer to a decent end. However the film could have made some effort to show that the actual trial which the film is based on actually took years to reach its final verdict instead in the film it feels like everything became well and fine within a couple of months which in the harsh and cruel reality of the Indian Judiciary,never happensSurya,who now has matured as an actor gives a very decent performance with just enough drama to make it entertaining while not over-doing it to the point of meladroma. Lijomol Jose gives her career-best performance though I found the use of black-face to be slightly offensive.The digital cinematography is just ok and does not have much signifance as this is heavily plot driven. I did see some fan theories of hidden symbolism. Editing was good. An odd thing about this script and screenplay is that it feels like it was written by two different people. It is clumsy,unrealistic and rushed in the first third while the rest two thirds is solid and straight. The score and songs of this film was really magnificent.It is the turn which the film takes after the second act which made me give 8 stars instead of 7 while it is the overall clumsiness which prevents me from giving this 9.In essence,a decent cinematic work with high ambitions and low execution but which offers good entertainment.

Jai Bhim" Tamil Movie Review......Released on Amazon Prime.... Directed & written by T. J. GNANVEL produced by 2D Entertainment...Verdict : Blockbuster......Lets go through the observation and mine review to this plot.....The story shows of.....1) The people belonging to low caste tribal people who are being squeezed and exploited badly by the society....2) How injustice can be done towards this group if the law is in the wrong people......3) "Hail Bhim" , " Victory for Bhim", slogan given by great Dr Ambedkar, but are these followed.... Still a question mark...The plot is based on a true story during 1995-96 in Tamil Nadu where a a group of low caste tribal are the prey for the merciless society non justifiable activities and how Advocate Chandru played by Suriya fights forms the rest part of the story....Performance wise, Lijomon Jose who portrayed the tribal women had given a spectacular performance.. Scenes where we cannot able to see, she has delivered the best... Now she will definitely bag good roles in Malayalam films.....Suriya, whether its Soorari Pottoru, Ghajini, Kaka Kaka, he has his own unique style of acting and that makes him different from other mass hero's....K. Manikadan portraying the tribal men also delivered the best performance... Cannot able to withstand on certain scene, as the director has able to take the shots very perfect, where a viewer will be in tears after some time or just a take a pause to come back to normalcy.....Film had shot an arrow towards the biased political system and the biased law where justice is a dream for many people who by their " low caste" stamped in their life being deprived their fundamental rights.... Its very ashameful moment to realise the weak spineless law system.....But it also shows if people like Advocate Chandru, NCB officer Sameer Wankhede exists the law will not be sold off to the wrong society....Overall a movie to know, to realize the attrocity when the law is at the wrong plate.

reviews.review_title: Review and reflect, be able to face history, good!
reviews.content:
This is a powerful film that hits the inequality of class society in India in the 1990 s and exposes the inferiority of its class superiority and black gold politics. Perumalsami: "It is true that in order to uphold democracy, someone from some era has to become a dictator."
In such movies, there are always many scenes and shots that make people angry and shudder. Those in power ignore life as a matter of course. It is like a routine abuse of violence. The direct lens is even more intuitive than the horror film. But even if there are thousands of ugly things in this world, as long as there is a voice that is unwilling to be silent, the world will not be so bad.Jay Bim is light, Jay Bim is love, Jay Bim is the path of darkness to light, Jay Bim is the tear in the eye of millions of people.In fact, this situation exists in many parts of the world. We also need to face history and face reality, review and reflect, learn lessons, and reduce such bad things. Indian film music and dance, finally just right!

ManikandanJai Bhim means light....
Jai Bhim means love....
Jai Bhim means journey
From darkness to light....
Jai Bhim means tears
Of billions of people!

reviews.review_title: A real life incident based movie is Jai Bhim. In this movie, projected a real life hero as Villian. So this movie trying to make castes based violences in Tamil Nadu.
reviews.content: Rajakkannu, a tribal from Kammapuram near Virudhachalam in Cuddalore district, was taken to the police station in 1993 on a charge of theft and was later found dead after being severely tortured by the police during interrogation.Govindan (Vanniyar Caste) - a real life hero, a member of the Marxist Communist Party who had been helping the victims for 13 years, was responsible for bringing the perpetrators to justice and the victims from the end of the case.Controversy arose over the differences between the true story of the released JaiBhim movie and the storyline, as well as the fact that a particular character in the film was talking on the phone, with a 1995 Vanniyar Kalasam calendar on the back.Why not mentioned the real life Villian's name as Anthonysamy in JaiBhim movie?Why project the 1995's Vanniyar Kalasam calendar behind the scene?Why mentioned Gurumoorthy as Villian name and sounding"Guru" in JaiBhim's movie scenes?So JaiBhim team wants caste based violences in Tamil Nadu.

reviews.review_title: A gripping true story with one stellar performance..but sub par execution
reviews.content:
The best Indian dramas weave together a page-turning screenplay and fantastic acting with stirring lyrical music and seamless orchestration by the director.The former two factors drag this movie towards a 10/10.. However, the lack of the latter 2 factors drag the drama downDespite the 10/10 reviews, ( a clear issue towards the usability of the IMDB platform), this is not the best movie this year..Please view the breakup of the ratings by age and segment( how many rated 10/10 and how many rated the rest) - to get a good indication of the genuine rating for the movie
It is however the best screenplay of a story that needed to be told. The issue of police brutality in the developing world gets far less global media coverage. However, the scale and scope of the havoc it plays in the lives of the downtrodden is very real.Surya's acting chops come through in every single scene. The intensity he brings puts most other performers in his shadow( a number of whom are new and cannot be faulted) - except perhaps prithviraj.Lijomol, manikamdan , Rajisha and Guru are creditworthy too..However, the lack memorable music , with one really out of place song at the start during Supriya s introduction , shows a below par music direction(Sean Rolden)..
This robs the movie of some of its potential - especially when compared to the true great films that tackled important themes like this film attempts toHowever the greatest issue is with the direction and especially the editing( assuming the burden for this is shared by the editor and director)Jarring changes in tone, misjudged transitions and a general lack of unifying color - something visible from start to finish in masterpieces by the mani ratnams and imtiaz Alis of this world - pull this movie well below the usual benchmarks of great social and drama masterpieces produced before by Indian cinemaA definite must see for Suriya fans.. and the stirring true story that deserves more awareness...

reviews.review_title: An intense battle between security and law - may truth prevail!
reviews.content: You would imagine that security forces and law are the two sides of the same coin and must always work hand in hand. Not true! Jai Bhim is the narrative of a real life incident and some real people where a fearless lawyer fights for the basic human rights of the underprivileged against the police force, dealing fire with fire in a backdrop of adversity.When heavily Sengenni's (Lijo Mol Jose) husband Rajakanna and two other relatives, all from an underprivileged and socially deprived tribe in Tamil Nadu go missing from the police custody without a trace, she runs from the pillar to the post to urge the authorities to help search for them. With no financial or economic resources, the helpless Sengenni finally finds kindness in Chandru (Suriya), a fearless lawyer who firmly believes that the police machinery has been given too much latitude and have turned into a maleficent force against the poor. After studying the details of the incidents that had originally led to the arrest of the three men and the subsequent events as described by Sengenni, Chandru is certain that the policemen are concealing the facts and are behind their disappearance. He agrees to take up the case and files a habeas corpus petition at the Chennai High Court against the police department, seeking assistance from the government to trace down the missing prisoners whose crime hasn't been proven.Jai Bhim is an intense investigation and courtroom drama that unfolds macabre events with diabolical consequences. Faced against the Attorney General fighting for protecting the policemen, Chandru faces an uphill task to unearth the facts that will eventually unmask the ugly truth. The film directed by T. J. Gnanavel showcases the naked chasm between the educated and civilised society and the marginalised scheduled castes and tribes, and is a glaring instance of the inequality that exists without our realisation. One of the hardest hitting films of our times, Jai Bhim is undoubtedly one in the calibre of the arthouse films of the 80's directed by Shyam Benegal, Govind Nihalani, M S Sathyu and Adoor Gopalakrishnan, and should be promoted to be India's entry for Oscars. Suriya is mighty impressive as the upright human rights lawyer fighting the case outwardly dispassionately, but seething from inside. Lijo Mol Joseph is a resounding reminder of Smita Patil's intense performances, showcasing angst and pathos in the most heart-rending manner. Rajisha Vijayan, Prakash Raj and Rao Ramesh offer great support. Yet I must laud the performance of Tamizh as the evil S. I. Gurumoorthy, the perpetrator of the excessive torture on the hapless trio, to rouse awareness of what goes on pice lock ups and how far reaching the power machinery can go to protect the real criminals.Don't miss Jai Bhim - it offers a wide range of emotional turmoil and makes for a gripping watch, standing out as one of the best films of recent times.

This film is based on true events that took place in Cuddalore district in 1993. In the original story, Rajakannu, a member of the Andai Kurumbar tribe whose main occupation was making bamboo baskets and agricultural labour, was accused of stealing jewels from a house that employed him. Based on the complaint, Rajkannu was taken into police custody.After suffering torture at the hands of the police, Rajakannu died in custody. To cover up their crimes, the local police moved his body late into the night, disposed of it in the neighbouring Tiruchirappalli (Trichy) district and later claimed that he had escaped from custody. Rajakannu's wife Parvathi, however, did not buy this story and sought help to locate her husband. Finally, she found a lawyer of the Madras High Court, K Chandru, who joined her quest for justice.K Chandru, who would later on become a well-respected and popular judge in the Madras High Court, filed a habeas corpus petition in the same court. After a 13-year legal battle, the court adjudicated that this was a case of custodial death and the accused police officials were sentenced to 14 years of rigorous imprisonment for the murder of Rajakannu. In an interview with The News Minute, he recalls how the police attempted to bribe Parvathi and him during the case. Chandru responded by throwing out the suitcase of money and the police from his office.Getting Parvathi justice for the custodial muder of her husband, however, is only one among the many incredible contributions of Justice K Chandru for the marginalised and downtrodden.In his six and a half years as a judge of the Madras High Court, he disposed of 96,000 cases, a remarkable feat which was only possible because of his immaculate planning and organisation.

A Lockup death in a Tamilnadu Police station (India), was concealed by the police and an honorable Advocate cleverly investigate it and reveal the Truth to save the Justice. This the base of the Story.The script of the story and the acting by the stars are very much natural and fascinating. No cinematic tactics were handled.

The movie content and making is excellent.In his Brave & Bold attempt, Director TJ Gnanavel 's Jai Bhim (2 hours, 45 minutes long) flawlessly speaks about custodial violence, police cover-up, systemic corruption at a huge level, that is so hard to logically digest or reason out the whole truth and finally there would be no end to the entire picture. The blame game is never ending.I can add to this saying that Jai Bhim is actually truly-brutally honest, clear-cut reality filled with heart-wrenching scenes, that is sure to leave you feeling that there is more bad in this world than good.

Delicious
-Many praises go to SR Kathir for a splendid job on the lighting and choice of camera lenses. The drone operator had good control of the camera and really engaged us
-Jai Bhim proved that even though justice is trampled upon in corrupted societies, it can still prevail when people are united to stand for itBland
-Jai Bhim had sorrowfully the same atmosphere as many other movies addressing the injustice of tribal or lower caste communities. The film was more about glorifying Suriya the celebrity than the actual advocate role he was portraying. The score volume was too high, making it appear more like a heroic genre rather than accentuating the despicable state of events
-Jai Bhim was told in a very common way: show the torture of the marginalized communities, expose police brutality, and have a centralized heroic figure that the audience can admire. The screenplay was not relatable and could have had stronger dialogues and scenario
-Ooook....so Lijomol Jose (playing Sengeni) was 'darkened' in Jai Bhim to come across as a tribal woman....this is like the times when Hollywood used to darken white actors to play black roles. This is a little concerning that the production couldn't find an actual dark woman to play Sengeni. True, Lijomol is a celebrity and this helped with the movie's publicity, however, it sends a very alarming message about this type of mentality.

Jai Bhim is a well made movie but overrated.Positives:
Good acting by Surya, Manikandan and most of the cast. Court proceedings are quite realistic without overdramatization. Movie provide an insight into the plight of tribal folks and could help in a change of view. Pace and construct of the movie keeps you gripped despite the story being predictable.Negatives:
Movie is too long and should have been wrapped under 2 hours. Movie tries to cash on regional jingoism like the scene where a man is slapped for speaking Hindi. Police brutality is very commonly presented subject and not a new theme.Overall a well made movie but if you are hoping to see a ground breaking masterpiece going by the ratings, then sorry this is not.
I never ever seen like this movie befor.on of the my best movie.suriya acting very very nice good..next superstar of the world cinima.dirctor also very good story writting and screen play.

us following his inspirational character maran in "soorarai pottru". This movie is based on true story following the person K chandru who was a advocate in high court and (the retired high court judge in present ) who made a tremendous effort to bring the real culprits in front of law,who killed a tribe in custody torture on false accusations.❤this is a must watch movie ❤❤👌🏼

Definitely deserves an Oscar.If Atticus Finch is the greatest movie hero, then Chandru is the most underrated real life hero.This movie is a sobering reminder of the injustice and lack of accountability that plagues my beloved India.The poor dwellings in the mountainous forests reflected the state of deep racial problems and social injustice that still exists in my beloved India.The guy (Suriya) who played Chandru gave an amazing performance.This is my first film of Surya n I have become a huge fan of him.Also this is my first film of the lead actress Lijo Mol Jose and she gave an intense performance and her character Sengkani will make even the toughest skin to feel sad.This movie has the most brutal scenes of police brutality. More horrific than most horror films and very very frightening when u know that the movie is based on true events.The real life judgment of Rajakannu vs State of Tamil Nadu & Ors, has Parvathi's statement on the torture that she and her husband had suffered, the reality seems far worse than art.
This is best film ever seen in my life.This will be change in our society and our self life styl.I hope people like this film.We need to chenge in our lives.

Hats-off to all actors.

It really shows that next upcoming generation going to be intellectual with loads of humanity in them with no discrimination of skin colour, caste, religious, gender etc. Thanks a lot for the entire team of Jai Bhim for producing such an inspiring movie. reviews.review_title: A scathing reminder of the life of bottom 50% of India
reviews.content: The movie moved me and at times made me feel anger, disgust, helpless and over all a sense of failure, for being part of a society that enables the torture of the downtrodden.The movie grips you and leaves me with the sense of discomfort at my own privilege. Suriya as Chandru and Lijomol Jose as Senginni are moral compass of the story. Prakash Raj as a IG Perumal is understated and completely blends into the character. In the end, the pain in the eyes of Senginni and her quiet struggle leaves you with tears.This is the story and many more that need to be told for the future of India.

Distorted facts from the actual events to vilify one community.Caste based discrimination is the crux of the movie and yet the castes have been conveniently changed to present discrimination which doesn't exist.

Tamil cinema is on a wave of social justice movies for the past few years. This is another brave attempt among those movies giving a more open and darker reality than the previous ones of this genre. Police station scenes are complete rampage. One might easily be reminded of Visaranai.The main themes are emotionally punching. There are one or two punches missed though. Some scenes are clearly bit exaggerated and higher than needed on the emotional tone. So there are one or two punches missed. If not so, this would have been the masterpiece.Acting is terrific from everyone. Sad not being able to mention everyone here. Lijomol was the best. Hope she does more Tamil movies. It's surprising to see such a huge cast handled perfectly. Usually movie focuses on the lead characters. Here even the star Surya doesn't rise above the other cast. He proves his uniqueness among other Kollywood stars. It's sad n
Songs are well suited to the tone of the movie. It's rare getting such songs with meaningful lyrics these days.Best part of the movie imo is the way the courtroom drama and crime investigation aspects of the movie are handled. Movie is more than 160 hours but never slows down anywhere. So racy is the screenplay.
